learning_outcomes.description: Deconstructs occupational injustice issues by gathering information about the social structures involved, implications for occupational engagement for communities/societal groups/populations, relevant human rights issues, world-level critical perspectives, those affected by the issue and those who might have influence over the social structures involved.

Collaborates responsibly and respectfully with peers, clinical educators, other health professionals, teachers, community organisation staff, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, and people from marginalised/disadvantaged groups.

Formulates complex plans that consider and respond to occupational injustices for communities, societal groups and populations resulting from unjust histories, political structures, cultural disadvantage, societal inequities, environmental issues, and economic factors that influence health, wellbeing and occupational engagement.

Implements plans targeted at community/societal/population client groups that consider and respond to occupational injustices by addressing structural barriers and building on structural enablers to engagement.
Produces digital media content to address occupational injustices and to work towards social change by drawing on relevant self-directed learning resources related to digital media and technology.

Critically analyses experiences in complex socio-cultural contexts to arrive at new understandings which can shape future reasoning and decision making including consideration of practice contexts, the multiple perspectives that influence interactions, evidence and theory.
Reviews outcomes of social change interventions based on planned objectives and data sources.

Questions their own and others practice and professional role using a strengths-based approach to support open, respectful and effective reflective group communication which aims to inform future reasoning, decision-making and practice that is driven by a combination of experience, theory and evidence.

assessments.task_description:
The Social Change Academy is a community of occupational therapy students connected over time through an online platform to build knowledge by progressing their own understandings and sharing their learning and reflections. Entry-level students have access to the Social Change Academy and the learning that occurs though the academy stays with them as they progress through their careers. The vision for The Social Change Academy is that the knowledge, understanding, and skills developed through the academy will shape the ways in which occupational therapists of the future will practice and have flow-on effects for our most disadvantaged and vulnerable client groups. In previous years, the social change academy included video descriptions of occupational injustices. In 2024, your informational graphics will be downloaded by course staff and added to the Social Change Academy site for future students to view and use in preparation for examination in the first year of their studies.


See the Task Description File on Blackboard.

assessments.task_description:
This individual assessment piece includes a sessional placement at the Murri School (The Aboriginal and Islander Independent Community School) in Acacia Ridge in conjunction with the Institute for Urban Indigenous Health (IUIH).


You will attend the Murri School, and engage in

o  delivery of sessions

o  communication with teachers, peers, clinical educators (e.g. in classrooms, in organising materials and resources, in debriefing sessions)

o  debriefing sessions which involve group reflections, critical thought and reflexive processes.


Student groups are expected to deliver the sessions independently. A clinical educator will be present and will step in to provide modelling, guidance and support if needed. Clinical educator feedback may be via direct comments to students, modelling of ways of interacting and engaging in the program or asking students questions (to prompt reflection). Clinical educators are also available to provide additional assistance in-line with the tasks that students are carrying out if asked by the student groups running the sessions.

 



See Task Description Document on the Blackboard.
